author: Chthroop
body:
Hi.  Thanks for the write up and you rightly point to the need for excellent commercial execution

I think we should be very clear on who the peers are for $PLTR.  

In no way is $SNOW a peer. Snowflake is a next generation, true cloud database . It’s a full SAAS model and it’s extremely strong at data analytics (though it can do true database work in a pinch).   It’s a general purpose tool that’s very simple to start using and requires zero setup and almost zero support.  Competitors include Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery etc

Compare this to $PLTR which is really an analysis / data integration platform that’s highly customized to users (so far mostly government) and has historically had a huge consulting requirement to setup.  

$Ddog is also not a good comparison as it is an application, stack and now database monitoring toolset.  

So, who are the good comparisons /competitors? IBM Watson springs to mind.  But probably the best i can think of that’s publicly traded is Alteryx $AYX.  However Palantir is much “heaver” even that Alteryx

Anyone have some better comp ideas?

author: hopeitshelpful
body:
This is a hard yes.  It’s great you’re seeing this trend, but it is nothing new, is fundamental to successful business at scale and is important to understanding both competition and the deflationary effects of technology.  

Look at almost any business and you will see how it has been incrementally automated over the last 100 years.  It is necessary (not sufficient) to maintain as much automation or more than your competitors in order to scale and meet inevitable price deflation/“cost efficiencies”.  Think about the printing press to automate writing copies of books, IBM digital computers automating human “computers” (brilliant subplot of Hidden Figures movie), Xerox machines automating rapid copying of documents in the 70s/80s, email automating the postal service, industrial factory automation over the last 70 years, etc.

The rule for companies is they must adapt/evolve or die.  No other option unless you have a government-enforced monopoly (eg, patent protection or regulated utility).  

Workers face the same pressures, and their continually improving standard of living depends on it.  


Source: am advisor to various Fortune 500 and tech companies, and my IP specialists help these companies find innovations used by competitors and other industries to stay ahead of the curve.

author: Difficult_Delay_8604
body:
If you want to learn about technical analysis

* Learn about trend indicators e.g. moving averages, momentum indicators e.g. Oscillators, volatility indicators e.g. Bollinger Bands, Volume indicators e.g. Chaikin Money Flow
* Support and resistance lines
* Read some books about technical analysis. This one is a good overview but it focuses more on futures but the stuff is generally applicable to stocks as well: "Technical Analysis of the Financial Markets: A Comprehensive Guide to Trading Methods and Applications". Use z-lib or some other book pirating sites
* Try and stay away from price action because that's the most suspect of all technical analysis. On the other hand, algorithmic/system trading is arguably the most rigorous of technical analysis based strategies.

If you want to learn about fundamental analysis

* Learn about multipliers and other fundamentals e.g. P/E, EBITA, EV.
* Learn how to make financial models e.g. Here's Martin Shkreli teaching how to build a financial model with IBM as an example [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM) (disclaimer, I think this particular valuation turned out to be wrong so focus more on the techniques/models used rather than specifics about the companies) and here's DeepFuckingValue valuing GME [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U). I think they make this type of dry stuff more "accessible" for the average person?
* Read some books. I've heard intelligent investor by Benjamin Graham is good, although I haven't read it so see what the others here think

But honestly, just buy ETFs and save enough to retire.

author: rawbdor
body:
Hedge funds shorted gamestop. Hedge funds shorted gamestop to a degree where there were more shares out short than existed. This was problem number one. 

When you buy shares in your brokerage account like interactive brokers or ameritrade, you are technically buying from your broker. If your broker doesn't have the shares, he has to buy them from the market. This is usually fine, because whatever price your broker pays, your broker will charge you, for those shares. If you want to buy 100 shares of gamestop, and your broker doesn't have the shares, he will check the acquire the shares (with your money) from the national best ask. However, your broker now needs to wait 3 days for whoever he bought them from to deliver them. They are allowed up to 3 days to deliver the shares they sell you. 

At the same time, huge volume of options were being traded in Gamestop. Tons of wsb apes bought options to the tune of 250 million shares. Only 50 million shares actually existed. Market makers and options sellers sold options to buy tons of shares because these market makers usually make tons of money selling options that expire worthless. Options brokers like Citadel sold tons of calls that they expected to expire worthless. If those calls expired in-the-money, Citadel (and others) would need to deliver 250 million shares to the people who purchased those options. Only 50 million shares existed. So now, not only did you have too many shares short (where everyone who was short was fucked), you also had options sellers effectively short (because the promised to deliver 250m shares that they didn't have).  

The options sellers needed to find 250m shares, Only 50m existed. The options buyers (normal folks on robinhood or ameritrade) were therefore owed 250m shares, but only 50m existed. If the options sellers could not deliver those shares, your broker (robinhood / ameritrade) would have been forced to go buy the shares on the open market. Remember, when you buy a call option, your counterparty is your broker. But your broker goes and gets it from somewhere else. Their counterparty is the options seller or the clearing house or somewhere else. If you buy a call option, you give your broker the $200, and he is your counterparty. But he takes your $200 and goes to citadel, and says "Citadel gimme that option" and Citadel says "Ok, gimme the money". Then it goes to the clearing houses for a few days for the trade to clear. 

 money. Your broker (Robinhood) owes  you 100 shares. The options seller (Citadel) owes your broker (Robinhood) 100 shares. But they're trading through a clearinghouse, who has guaranteed the trade. So, if Citadel does not deliver the 100 shares to your broker, your broker has to deliver 100 shares to you anyway. He will need to go to the market and pay absolutely any price to get it. Your broker will then go to the clearinghouse and say "You were supposed to give me 100 shares. You didn't. So I had to go buy it myself, again. You have to pay my bill".  The clearinghouse will go to Citadel and say "I was supposed to give 100 shares to Robinhood to give to Jimbob, but you never gave me the shares. Jimbob wanted his 100 shares. Robinhood had to pay $1000 for them. Robinhood wants me to cough up $1000. I just did. Now you need to cough up that $1000 to me."

This is the cascade. But remember, 250 MILLION shares were due to be delivered, and only 50 million existed. If the above situation happens on an IBM or a MSFT, it's probably not a big deal. The stock may rise 5-10% or something, but ultimately it's not an issue because there are plenty of shares available. But what if there are no shares available, and the people who own the shares refuse to sell at any price, and the options sellers MUST deliver the shares to teh clearinghouse so that they can deliver them to the brokers who can deliver them to the customers? What if the shares simply do not exist? 

Now you have a problem. Jimbob wants his shares. Robinhood tries to buy from the market, but there's almost zero available, and they sell for $10,000 per share. Robinhood cannot deliver the shares to their customers. Robinhood goes bankrupt, and goes to the clearinghouse and demands a solution. The clearinghouse goes bankrupt. The clearinghouse sues every counterparty to help deliver the shares. The counterparties go bankrupt. Citadel now can't repay any of their normal business operating debt, so the big banks lose billions. Stocks start tanking as everyone sells everything just so they can have cash to try to buy gamestop shares form the wsb apes who refuse to sell at any price. The market tanks, leading to any leveraged funds to go bankrupt. Etc etc etc.

author: GroceryBright
body:
Rule #1 Stonks only go up
Rule #2 don't forget rule #1

NVIDIA and AMD are sexy right now, revenue and profits increased, great products, great potential but way overpriced.

Intel is solid, probably underpriced, but the last few years have been poor in terms of product sentiment. AMD kicked their buts with their CPUs. Apple ditched them and released some of the most powerful CPUs in the market.

Even if they deliver a great GPU in the coming months, their brand has been stained after years of reashing products, selling them for very high prices and no innovation. This is the main reason Apple ditched them and AMD as surged and is the darling of gamers and in the server space.

So Intel have a lot of work to do. They would need to compete with AMD on price, with Apple on performance and power consumption and probably with NVIDIA on computing power (GPUs).

My sentiment is that they are so far behing everyone else that in a few years they could be to CPUs and GPUs what IBM is today for PCs...

Obviously this is my bear scenario. They could turn it around and become an amazing company again, but my sense is that they need to really innovate very quickly in order not to lose any more market / relevance.

Happy to be challenged on my thoughts.

For the last 20 years or so I have been jumping between Intel and AMD CPUs.

Before 2004, Intel probably.
2004 - 2008 AMD
2008 - 2018 Intel
2018 - AMD

AMD were dead around 2014 and they turned it around. Maybe Intel will manage to do it too.

author: notherday11

author: neuromancer88
body:
Possible, but I don't think it's likely

1) Vertical integration is not really an advantage. It can be when you've got a monopoly and the market is booming (ie. run the factories at max capacity and sell everything you make). During a downturn you're stuck with a whole bunch of fixed costs which don't allow you to properly "flex down"

2) You can make a chip that beats the competitor across the board, BUT... 

* is it as cost effective to produce? die size, manufacturing yields, etc..
* even if both are equally cost effective... just the fact that AMD is now competing, Intel will never get back to the margins they printed during their dominant/monopoly phase

3) Chip shortage... Intel makes a few kinds of chips and you can't take a broad based, global chip shortage and say that they will benefit. They primarily benefit when there is a shortage in PC related chips. They cannot simply decide to start making automotive chips

Sure, you can **project** a similar trajectory to MSFT... but MSFT is a rare unicorn which makes Satya Nadella one of my most admired CEOs. There are many more IBM, GM/Ford, Wang/Digital, Dutch East India Co, AT&T, Nokia/Blackberry out there than there are MSFTs. **THIS** is what I would project.

author: ddropthesoap
body:
Was also Software Engineer at Big3 Cloud providers ( not including IBM ). I like Digital Ocean, but I'm not sure the upside is high. I had leaps at $105, and that went up 1500% and closed that position. DOCN is long, multi year play. Even Citron called $200 P.T., which is a lofty upper bound. I think $130-$170 is a realistic P.T. for DOCN over the next few years unless they have some blow out quarter.

CloudFlare is uniquely positioned among cloud with a unique product line, including leading on serverless / edge computing.

Digital Ocean is competing on VMs which is a margin business. The question is, how large is the niche for an easier-to-use cloud for hobbyist and smaller scale web applications? They already have a million users. How many developers are out there? This is unlike Shopify which has a much larger addressable demographic. They've been able to increase average spend per developer, but it's not a  multi-bagger.

author: BrianKronberg
body: Quantum cloud computing.  A 53 qubit quantum processor solved a problem in 200 seconds that would take the fastest super computer 2.5 billion years to solve.  IBM just announced a 120 qubit quantum computer and has a 500+ coming and a 1000+ slated for 2023.  They will be the new mainframe.  So much faster than any normal servers for specific workloads and so expensive that you will want to rent time on them instead of building your own.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
I posted about the McDonalds deal last week, a few people are talking about them.😉

>most big companies spinoff apart of their business because well it’s to unload all the garbage debt that the parent company (IBM owns). So all bad debt now going to that spinoff company

The real problem is that IBM has a longstanding, very successful managed IT services division. 30 years ago that was high margin, but now it is low margin. And now they're more focused on cloud services. These units are directly competing. And it creates confusion for existing customers. By spinning off the old-school part of the IT consulting services, they clarify things a lot. It can be awkward to negotiate contracts when you're competing with yourself. And the industry has moved strongly to "hybrid cloud," with multi-vendor support, so they can get more money from the managed infrastructure clients in the spinoff, where those clients might choose some other cloud provider. And IBM can stay focused on being a cloud and AI provider.

Kyndryl isn't full of debt it is just low-margin and contains a lot of harmful redundancy that may thrive separately.

IBM has been doing major partnerships for almost 100 years, they're not the sort of company that creates a bunch of debt they can't pay and have to stuff in a suitcase. Check their credit rating.

The Palo Alto deal sounds really good, that could be a big winner for both. The Cisco deal will likely be irrelevant unless Cisco finds a better angle for a 5G play. The Boston Dynamics thing may be pretty good, but it is always hard to tell with BD if it is just going to result in nice videos. The Raytheon thing is good for Raytheon in the short term, and in the very-unlikely event that quantum computing actually impacts computer security in the next 100 years, it will help them both to have a working relationship in place.

IBM has a lot of other stuff going on too. They recently signed a deal to take over Honda's European finance and procurement operations. They've been "global allies" with Deloitte for over 20 years are going to offer a new AI-backed anti-fraud service to governments, for example to identify tax fraud.

Most of what they do flies under the radar, but they've got a lot going on, and the extra free cash flow they'll get from spinning off the legacy IT will really help them.

author: Pass_Little
body:
No, it's not compariable.  Yet it is.

The underlying principle here is this:

Winners Rotate.   

In 2000,  you would have been convinced that tech was the future because of the behavior of tech pre-2000.  And you should definitely buy it.

In 2007 you would have made the argument that tech hasn't done well since well, look at the last 10 years.  So you should buy anything BUT tech.

Now in 2021, the argument is that tech has done well the last 10 years so you should buy it.

Is tech going to crash like it did in 2000?   Not likely.   

But I do believe that the FAANG stocks are going to be replaced over the next 20 years as the top performers, just like GM, Walmart, Exxon, Ford, GE and IBM were over the last 20.       Even over the last 10 there have been drastic changes at the top of the pile.

You can pick pretty much any market segment and see periods where you thought it was the best thing ever, based on the past 10 years of performance.   And in many, if not most cases, each of those segments did more poorly the following 10 years.  Generally you can only tell what did well, not what will do well.

body:
Over 10 years the total return for IBM with dividends is 9.86%, less than 1% a year. After taxes it's negative. 

Their buyouts went on far longer than five years. They were nonstop from 1986 til Rometty left. Here's a very good summary: [https://www.discerningreaders.com/an-ibm-case-study-do-stock-buybacks-work.html](https://www.discerningreaders.com/an-ibm-case-study-do-stock-buybacks-work.html)

The company turned to financial engineering rather than making use of the highly dedicated, intelligent staff they began the 1980s with. They fired the people they had promised lifetime employment to. Outsourced everything they could and spun off the rest.  Shortsighted management paid no attention to those in the trenches who had good ideas. It was a tragedy for what had been a wonderful company.

author: mrh0057
body:
Claims made by wall street veterans (people who discovered Enron, Bernie Madoff, etc).  These are acquisitions and haven't been proven yet.

Telsa, GE, IBM, Facebook, the new alternative assets, SPACs,

Proven:

Theranos, Wirecard, Nikola, Wells Fargo, JP Morgan

Jim Chanos who discovered a lot of the frauds in the 80s, 90s, and 2000s says right now it's worse he has seen which is amazing since the 80s(S&L, Junk Bonds, etc.) and 2000s(Enron, Global Crossing, World Com, most of the mortgage industry, rating agencies, insurance, Madoff, Investment Banks, etc).

It's not possible to predict when exactly it will happen but as debt builds up the more unstable the system becomes.

author: Investing8675309
body:
There’s a reason nobody is talking about IBM. They’re a garbage dump backwater of tech that has missed every big trend since the mainframe.  Surprised these press releases didn’t include Watson. Long period of declining revenues and earnings and a slew of terrible CEOs (jury still out on Krishna, losing the Red Hat CEO was a bummer).

The Kyndryl spin-off is smart. They should jettison off Red Hat if they had any sense and just focus on being a contract solutions provider to large enterprise. This will still be the same IBM unfortunately after the spin off.

I don’t understand why in the world anyone would buy this over companies that provide real cloud - ie Google. The rest of you can keep hawking IBM’s quantum, cloud, and AI expertise without having a clue what you’re talking about.

author: Otaehryn
body:
I think they only cut small amount of company (6-9bn market cap), so this will not hugely affect them, except for less overhead.

I think the underlying Red Hat business still has 20% growth but they are not optimal at managing it. I think it will take couple of more years for this to reflect on IBM growth, so I plan to continue holding. Price is also cheap now if you want to enter.

author: stickman07738
body:
Remember you need to remember that quantum computing will require significant cash and companies will need to be well-financed (like GOOG, AMZN, IBM) or need to continually raise capital typical by additional stock offering - this will happen to many small / new players.   

HON is well financed but their quantum computing division is [proposed to merge](https://fortune.com/2021/07/21/honeywell-cambridge-quantum-computing-error-correction-quantum-volume-breakthroughs/) with Cambridge Quantum Computing - this is the one I am watching as they have been working in the area for over 10 years and are well-financed.

body:

body:
Honestly some of the "best value" companies (looking at fundamentals) are those in "unattractive" industries... Exxon Mobile, Phillip Morris, Smith and Wesson, Dow Chemical....you get the idea.

Oil, cigarettes, guns, industrials...they aren't fancy, but they make money.  Check out "The Growth Trap:  IBM vs Standard Oil" and some Jeremy Siegel.

author: kokatsu_na
body:
At a glance, from what I've seen, the quality of their voice-to-text is about the same as AWS/Azure produce or even better. The main problem with let's say Azure, is that text sometimes doesn't make any sense. Houndify can produce meaningful text and catch more nuances, voice recognition is great. But at the other hand, their text-to-speech sounds robotic. AWS/Azure is better in this field. Also, adoption of Houndify among developers is still quite low.

So it's more about contextual meaning. Their closest competitors are "IBM Watson Speech to Text" and Alexa I think (I might be wrong). The good thing about SoundHound is that they partnered with many car producers such as Hyundai, Mercedes-Benz, Honda, Daimler AG, which is a good sign for me. Can guarantee a long-term growth.

I still need to take a second look, but so far it looks pretty promising 👍 Probably gonna invest in it.

author: FactualNeutronStar
body:
Maybe some companies in the next 10 years explode to become $10T market cap because of some revolutionary innovation, but there is really no reason believe Microsoft, Google, Apple, and Amazon are not here to stay. They are massively profitable and sitting on massive piles of cash. 

GE and IBM failed to innovate which, as far as I can tell, the current leaders have vowed to do the exact opposite. Exxon failed to adapt to the changing energy environment and accrued massive amounts of debt. And Walmart... is still not a bad investment.

author: badgebruce
body:
IBM CEO Arvind Krishna said Thursday that his firm's spinoff of Kyndryl Holdings (NYSE:KD) gives Big Blue "the portfolio that allows us to grow" and provides it with sufficient cash flow to invest in R&D while still maintaining its dividend.  
Krishna, who also serves as the company's chairman, told CNBC that the firm now has a portfolio focused on growth centers like Red Hat, automation, security and consulting.

body:

I realize that it looks fantastic now, but at one point we've also thought that about Microsoft, and all of a sudden Apple and Google have overtaken them left and right for making some failed decisions. 
Batterywise their competitors are already at their level. And Waymo is strong too. It's really just the car companies that need to get there shit together.

They look good, cause the other car manufacturers were old dinosaurs. Like what MS or Apple were to Compaq and IBM. But new players are always joining the market and change things too.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
These are both risky because they have a lot of expectations built in. For example, the price rise that NVDA got out of the ARM acquisition announcement presumes that they intend to behave in a monopolistic way, and can squeeze that market without vendors switching to RISC-V. And that the won't receive any significant regulatory response. Otherwise, the acquisition price makes no financial sense at all, it is just tossing money out the window. 

INTC has similar problems. People are bullish because they're building a fab. When they tried to contract out use of their existing fabs in the past, they did very poorly at it; they were greedy, they were unwilling to offer competitive prices. And when people wouldn't pay a premium just to have the honor of being their customer, they discontinued the service instead of lowering prices. And they made a lot of excuses about what had happened.

Basically none of that is going to find its way into either technical or fundamental analysis. That is why I don't touch either of these stocks, and I prefer companies like AMD, AMAT, and even IBM. (What I like about IBM is that the bear case has been very popular, everybody can say something bad about them, and yet they're doing a great job of integrating their AI tools with the cloud and providing quality APIs to developers; and they're doing that while maintaining high margins and large revenue)

author: sskyzz
body: That’s what everybody probably thought about Kodak/IBM/GE

author: Difficult_Delay_8604
body:
If you want to learn about technical analysis

* Learn about trend indicators e.g. moving averages, momentum indicators e.g. Oscillators, volatility indicators e.g. Bollinger Bands, Volume indicators e.g. Chaikin Money Flow
* Support and resistance lines
* Read some books about technical analysis. This one is a good overview but it focuses more on futures but the stuff is generally applicable to stocks as well: "Technical Analysis of the Financial Markets: A Comprehensive Guide to Trading Methods and Applications". Use z-lib or some other book pirating sites
* Try and stay away from price action because that's the most suspect of all technical analysis. On the other hand, algorithmic/system trading is arguably the most rigorous of technical analysis based strategies.

If you want to learn about fundamental analysis

* Learn about multipliers and other fundamentals e.g. P/E, EBITA, EV.
* Learn how to make financial models e.g. Here's Martin Shkreli teaching how to build a financial model with IBM as an example [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM) (disclaimer, I think this particular valuation turned out to be wrong so focus more on the techniques/models used rather than specifics about the companies) and here's DeepFuckingValue valuing GME [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U). I think they make this type of dry stuff more "accessible" for the average person?
* Read some books. I've heard intelligent investor by Benjamin Graham is good, although I haven't read it so see what the others here think

But honestly, just buy ETFs and save enough to retire.

author: Afrofreak1
body:
We are talking multiple years here if not decades. Companies like Exxon. a.) They are in a dying industry and have been unsuccessful in pivoting away from fossil fuels to alternative sources of revenue. b.) They are a poorly run company that has had multiple CEOs in the past 10 years. c.) They have had declining revenue since 2014. d.) They are not reinvesting a lot of their profits back into the business because so much of it is released to shareholders as dividends. They know that that is one of the few reasons they are still in a lot of portfolios and ETFs. "tHey pAy a HeAlThY dIvIdEnD." Yes, but as a result they are backed into a corner and their business plan is basically: Extract as much value from the business as possible while we still can. 

Does that mean that you can't make money off Exxon stock? No, ofc not, and in fact it's one of the best performing stocks in the S&P500 this year. However, a company that has peaked without any contingency plan to continued growth will never be able to match the returns of a company like Microsoft or Google that are growing 20+% Y-o-Y top and bottom line. I will happily pay a premium to companies that have an outstanding track record and ample room to grow and, more importantly, *the proven ability to seek out alternative sources of revenue*. That is not priced in because we don't even know where these companies are headed until they tell us. I am putting my faith in Nadella and Pichai to lead those companies to growth opportunities that investors hadn't even considered yet. 

Meanwhile back at Exxon they are just doing damage control to make sure that their dividend is paid at all costs. That is a terrible investment strategy and the difference in returns over the past decade show it. How likely is it do you think that Exxon will continue down this path and likewise for Microsoft and Google? I do not want companies that don't have a bright future ahead because the potential for sizeable returns is just so much smaller. Unfortunately, companies like Exxon still occupy a sizeable chunk in the S&P500 because once-upon-a-time Exxon in particular was the largest company in the world by market cap. As a result, it drops the S&P500s total return hence why I went with the NASDAQ-100. 

It's not that I'm actively *picking* tech stocks, it's that I'm *removing* chronically underperforming companies like Exxon, Chevron, Wells Fargo, IBM, Ford, GM, etc. and the NASDAQ is the most similar to what an ideal portfolio would look like.

author: mrkaluzny
body: Don’t sell AAPL. I think they’re going to 200 in 22 (depends on chips shortage) new MacBooks are flying off the shelves AAPL is supply bound but the margin on their own devices is higher then Intel-based ones. And this is not priced in IMO.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
1. Intel has been heavily supporting their share price, where would it be without them? Sub $40?
2. Their p/e ratio reflects their market saturation, who are they going to steal market share from? They are the incumbent.
3. And they will need every cent to build new fabs.
4. Never say never, Intel is going to have to take on massive debt, in addition to the 30B they carry at present, to fund IDM2.0. If the CFO is looking for cash the dividend is easy pickings.

Their new weird CEO has stated intc is aiming for leadership in 2025, 3-4 years away. One thing to remember is this super cycle aside, the semiconductor biz is cyclical, boom and bust. In 3 or 4 years when demand drops off and both TSMC and INTC have built massive chip foundry capacity, where will the customers go? To the foundry with the best process. Whoever has overbuilt will suffer.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
> The nm stuff isn't really accurate for any of them anymore so not worried about a rebrand.

Gate leakage and ultimately performance per watt is the real measure of a process. If one compares Tsmc and Intel fabbed processors on what both call 7nm, the tsmc silicon is easily better.

author: Gy7479
body:
Well you create an account with them, then open a BTC or Eth wallet and send your crypto using the wallet adress (Bitcoin to Bitcoin, Eth to Eth). You have one free withdrawal per month, no length terms. Blockfi is only lending to institutions. Please take the time to read their whole website and FAQ, and take the time to read about sending and receiving cryptos, gas fees (transfer fees that you pay for every transaction), etc. I treat my cryptos like my stocks: long term hodler, passive income, aiming for 5% in cryptos for my portfolio. Mainly Btc and Eth, will add a few smaller coins eventually. 

As usual, not your keys not your coins warning.
